Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Uncertainty Quantification and Model Validation in Thin-Walled Structures: A Probabilistic Paradigm for Advancing Analysis-Based Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will pursue research towards an advanced framework for nonlinear stability analysis of thin-walled structures taking into account the uncertainty associated with geometric imperfections. Thin-walled structures most commonly fail in buckling failure mode. Whether this buckling is benign or catastrophic depends, to a great extent, on the details of the structure, most importantly its geometric imperfections. The research aims at providing a leap towards uncertainty quantification and model validation in the analysis of thin-walled structures by devising a probabilistic paradigm that uses advanced uncertainty quantification techniques along with novel structural analysis methods. Methodologies for the characterization and representation of geometric uncertainties as well as probabilistic imperfection sensitivity analysis frameworks are proposed that have the potential to pave the way for a fully stochastic nonlinear analysis of thin-walled structures. The proposed techniques are complemented by experimental measurements of imperfections with high accuracy, and testing of imperfect members.

If successful, the results of this research will transform how geometric imperfections are handled in advanced analysis-based design of thin-walled structures. Because of the very general and mathematics-driven nature of the stochastic approaches adopted in this project, the methodologies developed will be applicable to a wide variety of problems and will have potential impact across all science and engineering disciplines. Alongside graduate student mentoring, undergraduate research will be a focus of the efforts at both University of Massachusetts Dartmouth (UMD) and Johns Hopkins University (JHU). The involved undergraduates will be asked to share their experience with students at local high schools and a community college as well as students attending Freshman Summer Institute at UMD, in hopes that their success will be emulated by others. Also, in collaboration with programs that specifically target underrepresented groups, qualified students are invited to participate in research at both universities. In addition to academic dissemination through conferences and papers and providing all developed work as open source, the PIs will capitalize on their involvement in engineering committees (e.g. AISC, AISI etc.) to disseminate the findings outside of the academic community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Civil infrastructure from buildings to bridges and tunnels, and from wind turbine, power and communication towers to storage tanks, form the lifeline line of a society through providing the essential services, supporting social interactions and fostering economic development. Among structures, those made of thin-walled members and assemblages represent a natural evolution of engineering design where minimization of the material used is an important component of cost saving strategy. As the material is minimized the resulting structure changes in its response under load from a more predictable response to a response that is complicated with instabilities and very sensitive to imperfections. The prescriptive codes and standards used by structural engineering community has traditionally approached the design of thin-walled structures from a conservative angle. This has been done either through the implementation of large safety factors (often lading to inefficient and uneconomical designs) or ad hoc tuning of the design process (often lacking a quantitative measure for the reliability of design). 

In an attempt to shift the design of thin-walled structures from an excessively conservative practice, general analysis approaches are now being provided (though with little detail) in codes and standards. This procedures, however, are lagging behind recent scientific breakthroughs in collecting and analyzing data. Drawing upon these recent advancements to enrich the process of designing thin-walled structures was the focus of this project. Cold-formed steel members (plate thickness ~ 1mm, plate width 10-500 mm, length 1-3 m) made through roll-forming or press-braking thin sheets of steel were used as the initial archetypes for study. A novel imperfection measurement rig, capable of providing full 3D geometry of a cold-formed steel member with cross-section dimensions that fall within a 400mm diameter opening and less than 3m in length was developed. The rig employs a 2D profile laser (800 individual lasers) mounted on a linear and rotary stage to scan the part. The scanned data is then used to re-create (from 1000’s of measurement points) a full 3D image of the cold-formed steel member enabling both imperfection analysis and generation of geometrically realistic computer models. 

While measured imperfections provide an important gateway to the nature of imperfections in thin-walled structures, they only provide samples from a bigger population with a wide range of variability.  To be able to have a complete picture of the imperfection field with its spatially varying and uncertain character a novel framework based on machine learning and data analytics for generating artificial imperfections that share the same statistics as the measured imperfections was developed. Such artificially generated but statistically informed imperfections were then introduced into the models of cold formed steel members crating models that are as close as possible to physical reality.   Such realistic models, together with modern tools of uncertainty quantification, were then used as a means to exploring all the expected responses of a thin-walled member with different geometric imperfections and to quantify the credibility of the code prescribed procedures that are geared towards including the impact of imperfections in the design process.   

It is expected that the tools and methodologies developed in this project will lead to design of thin-walled structures that, while being efficient owing to their thin design, are measurably more reliable. The researchers involved in this project continue to work with partners in academia and industry to further promote analysis based and data-informed design of thin-walled structures in future standards and design codes.

 


Last Modified: 06/26/2018
Modified by: Mazdak Tootkaboni
